pros: The clients are lovely enough and friendly
cons: Your driving around all day and night , no petrol allowance, office staff are terrible, bullying and intimidating, mention anything they don't like and you have no work to " teach you a lesson" rotas all over the place , cancelling calls when your outside the property , non stop calls and messages , awfull company, avoid!

review_title: Zero hours contract literally means zero hours
pros: There isn’t any that I know of
cons: I was employed by age uk 3 months ago but still no work. I was told that I need business insurance for transport, that costs me an extra £15 a month. I’ve had to fill out lots of forms. I’ve had to attend a dementia course. But no they haven’t given me any work as a gardener. They are basically advertising fake jobs. I don’t know how it benefits age uk to do this. It’s a complete waste of my time and money though. When I asked about when there would be gardening to do they sent me leaflets in the post so that I could post them to find work. It’s very disappointing.

review_title: Top heavy, badly run and greedy
pros: Meeting some really lovely older people and feeling like the work you do makes a difference.
cons: Greedy management not making the right choices to help older people and not respecting or paying their staff a reasonable rate.

review_title: Fantastic place to work - sad to leave
pros: Age UK is a brilliant place to work. They have a clear purpose. They provide excellent services to older people. Staff care about what they are doing and are taken care of at work - that passion is not wasted. There is a wealth of professional expertise, lived experience is drawn upon, older people are consulted. Working for a known "brand" has its advantages, but I have always felt the reality lived up to the high expectations. Work culture is supportive. The current hybrid working situation works well, keep it flexible!
cons: The conversation around office and home working is a bit of company obsession. Keep things flexible - clearly some people need the office and some people really enjoy working from home - and sometimes both groups need to get together. We all need to respect our different styles of working - coming in for the sake of it can be stressful and expensive, let's all learn to embrace the hybrid style so everyone can work happily!

job_title: Personal Independence Associate in Croydon, England
pros: Amazing team and culture of company
cons: Pay isn’t great, could be much better

job_title: Digital Fundraising Lead in Exeter, England
pros:
- I think this depends on which team you're in. Some teams definitely had it easier/better in terms of workload and work/life balance.
- Opportunity to expand skillset and gain new experiences.
- Generally helpful and supportive colleagues (though not all).
cons:
- Far too much work in the team I was in, too much pressure and long hours worked.
- Lack of appreciation and real support from management.
- No real attention to employee wellbeing, it's mostly just lip service.
- Lots of siloed working and lack of integration with/understanding of other teams.
- CEO left very suddenly after a long tenure and it was brushed under the carpet.
- Lack of transparency over strategic priorities and direction.

review_title: This is about the National Age UK - not about local ones (they are all individual organisations).
pros:
Looks good on CV
Central location (Tavis House) in nice area of London.
Lovely cafeteria, open to the public.
cons:
Very limited personal develoment - i.e. only basic stock training ("how to be assertive") offered. Personally I was asking  for (a very much job related) training in assessing older people's mental health wellbeing, and was ignored for 4 years by my line manager and overlooked by their seniors. Rather unsafe situation, both for staff and service users. 
Some older staff seemed to have 'inherited' the management roles during the merger of Age Concern and Help the Aged back few years ago, and their management skills/training are near-non existent. I.e. to be a manager it takes more than being employed for more than 10 years in the same project. Personally I had the worse management experience in the 14 years of my career. 
No transparent pay scale.
There was no money for training, for pay rises, or even a team building exercises. But my line manager was employing her old friend (and their former line manager) as a freelance consultant for years. When challenged about it, it was argued it was good for business ('money well spent'), but suddenly the invoices stopped. Ignored by the senior management.

job_title: Marketing and Development Manager in Ashington, North East England, England
pros: Great team, strategic thinkers, hard working
cons: Would do more with more resources

cons: Constant hot desking as a part timer meant I always felt I was in someone else's seat and was harder to form solid relationships

pros: 5 years ago my husband became disabled and I started at Age UK, just to give us a break from each other. But 5 years on I have found it has given me so much more than just a break from being  carer. I work with a friendly hard working team, and am meeting new people on a daily basis. My confidence and self-esteem have been boosted and I feel like I am doing something worthwhile. Also (and I'm not just saying this) I have a great Manager in Sharon Rawle.
cons: Ever changing directives and targets from upper-management. It seems with alarming regularity a new rule or directive is thrown out with a blanket approach to all shops regardless of the economic demographic or location. What works for Oakham, will not work for Wigston (leics)! Also, as a long-standing volunteer, I found it most insulting to be told that although I can be trusted on the till to serve customers, upper management no longer considered a volunteer trustworthy enough to undertake any other transactions (e.g. petty cash, serving other volunteers). Please be careful how you treat your volunteers - you need us.

pros: Works with older sector to ensure full standards of living and independence are met

review_title: Disappointed by lack of career progression and trust
job_title: Junior Staff In the Services Division in London, England
pros: Lovely people (for the most part), a genuine desire to change things for the better for older people, most staff are committed and passionate at first.
cons: There is not enough trust in staff, except heads of department and some senior managers, to let them get on with their job and take responsibility, which would in turn lead to them achieving more and being more productive. Most colleagues I have spoken to have the same issues, that they feel they have to ask permission to do the smallest things, instead of being able to thrive and make decisions. This leaves staff feeling disempowered and disillusioned. Too much hierarchy and too little space in which to grow.

pros: This company offers the over50s great support and amazing affordable items for public to buy to support the charity and is a friendly place to work and visit. This company offers a comfortable place to work no matter what skills you may or may not have there support is welcoming and friendly and supportive.
cons: As this company is a charity it always needs more money to support the best services and care for staff and customers and this at times can be stretched and many staff are having to go beyond to keep things going.  However as a team it's what we do.

review_title: Only good if you are close to retirement or a student
pros: It is a nice and quiet place to work in if you just finished university.  Good to build up office experience for your CV.
cons:
If you are a more experienced person, but not at Manager level, don't expect to grow  inside the company. There aren't many chances to develop inside even though they give you the impression that there are.
Salary is low, you can get paid a lot more for the same job but at a different company/organisation (even for Managers).
Don't expect a salary raise or any other benefits, their excuse is always the same 'we are a charity, we can't afford'. 
The environment is pretty boring  for a young person and lacks innovation and forward-thinking.

pros: Lovely volunteers in the shops and some great managers.
cons: Managers not supported or encouraged to realise their potential, some worrying practices going on that are ignored by senior management, generally lagging behind in the retail world!

review_title: Massive ship with no-one steering it
job_title: Employed In Head Office in London, England
pros: In my team: nice people, supportive management, flexible working.
cons: Things move very slowly; lots of decision-by-committee. No clear vision or direction - seems to be moving away from being a charity helping vulnerable people, towards being a company trying to sell to them, but there is no direct acknowledgement of that and it feels like you're being pulled two ways at once.

review_title: Good organisation working for a  great cause
pros: Lots of training opportunities, really lovely colleagues, and a genuine commitment to working with older people to make late life better. Career development options including stepping up and taking on additional responsibilities. Quality is taken seriously, and impressive thought is given by colleagues as to how they improve and develop their work and this is generally  recognized and appreciated by managers
cons: As with most large organisation some of the internal procurement processes can be clunky, I.T. basics are a bit inconsistent, e.g. slow systems.

pros: In my experience not many came into the shop whilst I was there so it was never outrageously busy. If you feel liker you would like this kind of environment, then you should for sure apply for a job or apply to be a volunteer as volunteers are always needed and are useful to have in store to help out. There was only myself and the store manager some days, so we developed a good relationship. The work was easy enough and had no real issues with the other staff or the job itself.
cons: Can sometimes be boring because it's not very busy.

pros: Great potential with extensive contact to a massive breadth of older people, many of whom are vulnerable and actively seeking help from experts like Age UK. A trusted brand, with great potential to attract corporate partners. Also a huge base of customers (older people!) to flog useful stuff to! Not all older people are poor, so make money off some so you can help the rest!
cons: Disjointed, siloed, backward. Disinterested HR department. Over-complicated raft of pillars, missions, work focuses. Trying to be all things to all people.

job_title: Support Worker/Home Helper in London, England
pros:
Really knowledgeable, supportive and compassionate management.  Very thorough and appropriate training.  Opportunities for personal development and taking on new roles.

Service provided for older people is exceptional and covers a social need that is otherwise not being met adequately.  I cannot offer higher praise for this organisation.
cons: Financial - unfortunately support staff were paid just below the london living wage, when I was employed with Age UK.

review_title: Tom Wright has gone, things may finally improve
pros: Some lovely hard working people. A charity with some honourable intentions. Good mix of fundraising and commercial revenue streams. Great campaigning team. Fairly innovative e.g. The Wireless, plus new fundraising events
cons: No longer a con, for Tom Wright has become the Guide Dogs problem. Arrogant man with a huge ego. Into cronyism, lack of warmth or empathy. On two occasions couldn't even say thank you to me for holding the door open for him.

review_title: Un-family friendly / those wanting part-time hours forced to leave
pros: Some caring staff lower down the rungs and in middle management
cons:
A charity which doesn't like female employees to have children or grandchildren. 
Age UK Kendal Cumbria
Refuses to allow staff to drop to part-time hours and firmly refuses flexible working hours to women to balance family life.
Losing good staff due to the above of not allowing p/t or flexi hours.
Bombastic and unpleasant chief officer.
Extreme hierarchy re: senior management.
Very low paid for skilled positions with responsibilities. 
Best advice is don't work here. Better working conditions in local supermarkets.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Portsmouth, Isle of Wight, South East England, England
pros: Colleagues are pleasant to work with and environment makes you feel you do genuinely help people in need.
cons: Management can be predatory in the sense that you will watch your colleagues each in turn be put under intense stressful scrutiny, until they have a breakdown or quit. It will happen to you too.

pros: Age UK England strives to lead the market. In my experience they are quite forward thinking and push to shorten the gap between charity shops and the rest of the high street.
cons: Since it is a charity money is tight.
